fields.description:
I am following the instructions in order to build the parquet libraries, and there are some firewall restrictions in our dvpmt environment.

I have followed the instructions mentioned in [https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docs/source/developers/cpp/building.rst]

regarding Offline Builds: 
{code:java}
./thirdparty/download_dependencies.sh $HOME/arrow-thirdparty >env.sh
. ./env.sh
cd cpp
mkdir debug
cd debug
cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DARROW_PARQUET=ON -DARROW_DATASET=ON ..
make parquet arrow_dataset{code}
The result is that the process simply ignores the environment variables and tries to download the packages from the cloud - facing the firewall restrictions, and then it fails after a number of attempts at trying to download the packages.
h3.
fields.summary: [C++] offline builds does not use ARROW_$LIBRARY_URL to search for packages
fields.environment:
uname -a
Linux xxx.xxx 3.10.0-1160.11.1.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Dec 18 16:34:56 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

cmake -version
cmake version 3.9.0-rc4

comments.body:
Is it all environment variables that get ignored? Only some of them?

Here is the place where they should be inspected:
https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/cmake_modules/ThirdpartyToolchain.cmake#L336

My guess is that it's only the BZIP2 and UT8PROC environment variables that get ignored, because there seems to be a name mismatch (e.g. ARROW_UTF8PROC_URL vs. ARROW_UTF8PROC_SOURCE_URL):
https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/cmake_modules/ThirdpartyToolchain.cmake#L601-L618

The attached PR should fix this for bzip2 and utf8proc (I tested it locally after disconnecting my Ethernet).
Note that S3 and ORC seem to need Internet connectivity to build their dependencies, but that's a separate issue.

Hello,

Unfortunately it still doesn't work in my environment. For some reason, it
keeps trying to download from the URL, instead of copying from the local
path.

On Thu, Mar 25, 2021 at 11:41 AM Antoine Pitrou (Jira) <jira@apache.org>
Have you tried deleting the build directory and re-running CMake again?

Yes, that's the first thing I did.
arrow/cpp/debug/utfproc_ep-prefix/src/utfproc_ep-stamp/download-utfproc_ep.cmake
seems to be the problem. I uploaded that file.
It seems like, if the url is present, it tries to download it, even if it
has the local package in the local dir. And there comes the problem if
there are firewall restrictions.

On Thu, Mar 25, 2021 at 3:36 PM Antoine Pitrou (Jira) <jira@apache.org>

> It seems like, if the url is present, it tries to download it

What do you mean with "if the url is present"?

If the system can access the link.
Even though it cannot download the file.

On Thu, Mar 25, 2021 at 3:58 PM Antoine Pitrou (Jira) <jira@apache.org>
Which link are you talking about?

What I mean is, the url is visible, but the file cannot be downloaded.

On Thu, Mar 25, 2021 at 3:59 PM Daniel Blumenfeld <

Hmm... that doesn't make things clearer.
Are you sure you deleted {{arrow/cpp/debug}} ?

Sorry I was not clear.
What I mean is this:

In order to try the changes, I cut and pasted into my copy;
Then, I deleted all files under the arrow/cpp/debug folder;
Then, I repeated the cmake command;
Then, I repeated the make command.

It didn't work.

My assumption about why it didn't work is that this offline feature assumes
that the machine, besides having the environment variables set, needs to be
disconnected from the internet. I don't know where the point is where it
tests this condition.

Now, what happens if the machine is not offline (so the url
https://github.com/JuliaStrings/utf8proc/archive/v2.5.0.tar.gz is visible)
but the firewall does not allow the application to download it, so it goes
through the loop, failing every time?

My proposal is that, if the environment variable ARROW_UTF8PROC_URL is set,
just copy the file it points to, into the corresponding place instead of
even checking if the url is visible and trying to download it from
https://github.com/JuliaStrings/utf8proc/archive/v2.5.0.tar.gz.

I hope I made myself clear enough now.
Thank you.

On Thu, Mar 25, 2021 at 4:05 PM Antoine Pitrou (Jira) <jira@apache.org>

> My assumption about why it didn't work is that this offline feature assumes that the machine, besides having the environment variables set, needs to be disconnected from the internet. 

The feature doesn't assume anything like this. If the environment variable is set, it's used.
So, unless something else is wrong, my guess is that you made a mistake when pasting the changes from the PR.

You were right, the problem was the name of those precise environment variables.

The build process is progressing now. Thank you VERY MUCH.
